reviewText:
A pretty straight-forward tower defense game.  I really enjoy the pirate/nautical theme; I actually think it is a much more appropriate theme for a tower defense game as a waterway could require attackers to follow a set path at times and defensive towers could easily be constructed to hinder them.  In most tower defense games I always wonder why the attackers would only follow the roads, and why the defenders would rely on ranged stations rather than, say, an entire hoard of military units advancing on the invaders.

This game does have the same unit types as its predecessor, Royal Defense, but with different maps.  So if you enjoyed the first game you will enjoy this one, as it is another just like it.

The graphics have a vibrant, painted look to them and the art style is very pleasing with a degree more polish than some of the other tower defense games such as Kingdom Rush or Garden Rescue.

The music is pretty standard battle fair.  Decent enough background music for any military skirmish game, but I do wish they had included more of a jaunty pirate shanty as the mission music with a few more nautical sound effects for a much richer pirate-themed immersion to set this game apart from the other games of its genre.
voteText: 25 of 29 people (86%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Pro:
Decent graphics for a Tower Defense game.
Three difficulty levels.
Con:
Lazy, boring upgrade system that requires grinding.
Enemy paths sometimes unclear.
Poor targetting priorities.
Little variety in towers and only half of them are viable.
Crappy UI, Escape doesn't even open the menu.
No screen resolution options, just Windowed or Full Screen.
No keybinding option.
Terrible 10-second music loop.
Uninspired spells. Meteor Rain, really?
Very little variety in maps, the same map is used for 2-3 levels.
The publisher is so lazy the description still refers to collecting crystals like in Royal Quest.
Tutorial text (new tower/spell/enemy) plays every time you play a level, on every difficulty.
Adds nothing to the genre.
Conclusion

This game makes Royal Quest look inspired by comparison, and that is not a compliment. The whole thing is just lazy and uninspired, there are tons of better Tower Defense games out there, even free ones (like Cursed Treasure 2).

reviewText:
This is a great game however it is lacking two very important things that a lot of tower defense games have. If you can get past those two things than this game is really great.

The first problem with this game is that it's a tower defense with no endless mode, and - to make things even worse - very short levels. Everytime I feel like I'm really dominating the attacking enemies the level is over and I go to the next one and start building again. Not ever have I felt like the enemies were really requiring to use or upgrade even half of the map, no matter what difficulty I play on. The levels are simply too short to ever be really challenging after a couple of waves (The first few waves are often challenging though.).

My second problem is that a new wave cannot be started untill the last one is completely defeated. I've seen a lot of tower defense games and this is not something that every tower defense game has but since the game gets really easy after a couple of waves it would give players an option to make things more difficult at times.

The game is simply not challenging enough after a couple of waves in a level and there aren't enough waves in one level to actually require you to use and upgrade the entire map, meaning that you'll dominate the enemy since you'll have enough gold to actually place and upgrade enough turrets to fill the map after a few waves.

Apart from those two points the game is really good, but it just isn't a real tower defense without some kind of endless mode.

reviewText:
Fort Defense is a fine little Tower Defense game, a bit on the easy side, but more on that later.

It's easy to pick up and play, and you don't have a lot of different towers, but with individual customization as the game progresses. I picked up the game and without much trouble I beat all easy levels with 3 stars and went on to play on medium, but after a few rounds it still felt a bit too easy, so I played through on hard a bit better but still not that hard. So I immediatly started the next world on Hard, and the difficult level was more enjoyable. about 3 levels requires a good really good start.

So if you have played TD games before and want a bit of a challenge, try it on a harder level from the start. After playing through world 2 on hard, you have earned lots of barrels" (the ingame currency) and have unlocked multiple powerups.

Pro:
Easy to pick up and from starting the game to be ready in a level in takes around 5 sec.
Nice graphics
Nice levels
Quick rounds

Con:
No "nightmare" levels to spice up the difficulty a bit. Generally to easy.
Spells not that well balanced. Most of the time not needed at all.
Only 4 tower types
date: of which 2 is used a lot
hoursPlayed:
and the last can mostly be ignored.

Conclusion:
For that price it is absolutly worth it. Even though it lacked a bit in difficulty it was a very enjoyable experience. And I am looking forward to the developers next Tower Defense game.
"

reviewText:
A small and fun tower defence game. Though it's not adding anything new to the genre and is kind of generic, it's still fun enough and worth playing if you are into tower defence games. You get to play through 40 levels of naval battles. Build giant crossbows, cannons, and other mounted guns to take down pirate ships that are coming at your base kamikaze style.

The variety in enemy ships is quite big and each one has its own distinct weaknesses which you have to exploit via certain towers. The towers mostly come in 4 basic types, which in turn can be upgraded into other types. You have crossbows which are fast but weak. Cannons which are slower but strong. Artillery which are very slow but can hit groups. And finally the support buildings that generate you money on a regular basis, which I think is a pretty cool idea in a game like this.

The levels are divided into 2 acts: Caribbean Sea (first 20 levels) and Arctic Ocean (last 20). When you beat each level, you get a rating out of 3 stars. Not letting any enemy attack your base grants you 3 stars. If, however, some did manage to damage it, you get only 1 or 2 stars. Unfortunately the stars do not mean anything in this game. In other tower defence games the stars act as upgrade points of some kind, hence incentivizing the player to replay missions and do better. But this game doesn't do that and collecting stars is only there for boasting.

The upgrades are instead handled via collecting barrels, which randomly drop from destroyed enemies. There are tonnes of upgrades for each tower and magic spell, and you're unlikely to upgrade everything by playing through the game once. This means you might occasionally have to grind for barrels by replaying earlier levels, which is a bit of a bad design in my opinion (when in doubt, keep replaying level 20 of Caribbean Sea; it gives A LOT of barrels usually). What's worse about this design, some of the tower spots on each map are locked and require you to spend several of your barrels before you can build anything on those spots. Those are usually good, strategic spots, so you have to either waste some of your precious barrels on one map, or compromise on your setup.

Visuals are very beautiful and shiny. Sound effects are nice, and the music is all right, although you pretty much have the same short track playing in every level, so a bit more musical variety would've been nice.

Overall this is a fun TD game. There are better TD games out there, but if you're looking for a new one that you haven't played yet, then this one is well worth a try, since it's very affordable and will entertain you for several hours.

reviewText:
It's quite a fun tower defense game, with a few shortcomings. The visuals are nice while the music is just about OK. Difficulty is very front-loaded on each level - if you manage to get through the first two waves with a decent insfrastructure (ie. protected key points, 2-4 money generating towers), then the remaining waves are way too easy. The entire game is very easy - until you start the second campaign, which is more challenging even with all the upgrades in place. So it's fine, eventually.
My only serious gripe is unit diversity - cannon towers and money towers are way more efficient than anything else.
Even so, I can recommend this game.

reviewText: While not truly terrible, Fort Defense is a lacklustre, uninspired humdrum example of Tower Defense gameplay.  If you've played a TD game or two before, you've already played this one.  The most imaginative part of the whole game is the naval theme, which is purely an aesthetic matter, with no influence on the actual play.\n\nThe fact that the game uses a standard currency (gold) and a premium currency (barrels, though the recycled copy from their previous game still calls it crystals), that the premium currency is usable to make just about anything easier, and the low drop rate of the premium currency (requiring tedious grinding) all suggest to me that Fort Defense (or the predecessor game that they reskinned for Fort Defense) was originally designed to be a P2W mobile game, and selling it instead as a conventional game was a change of plans made late in the development process.

reviewText: Wow, another tower defense game.  I love these games! And it has an ocean theme, which is different that most.  This game has to be good, right?  WRONG!  I think I fell asleep playing that last level.  I made it through the first campaign, after what seemed like years of my life.  Everything is so repetitive, from the towers, the boards, even the music is the same five notes played over and over and over again.You can't see the icons for the tower bonuses, so it's all pretty much guesswork.  There's no variety in towers either.  There are 4 basic types, whic will upgrade three times, with the last one being a special" tower.  While this is common in most TD games
date: at least the highest iteration has some kind of effect on the game.  Not so here.  Even for the hardcore TD gamer
recommended: this one is a snoozefest.\n\n9/10 Would pass out again"
